questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serial vital signs for at least nine hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The severity of abdominal injury determines whether hemodynamically stable patients can be managed nonoperatively with serial monitoring of vital signs. Although unsupported by high-quality evidence, serial monitoring of vital signs for a period of 9 hours without imaging may be a reasonable approach following trauma for hemodynamically stable patients with a low risk of abdominal injury. This patient, however, has fallen from a height of 10 feet and has left upper quadrant pain and guarding, as well as a positive Kehr sign, all of which indicate a splenic injury that requires additional abdominal imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Abdominal CT with contrast is the most appropriate next step, following a negative FAST scan, in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected splenic injury. CT scan has greater specificity than ultrasonography for diagnosing splenic lacerations because it can visualize the vasculature and parenchyma of the spleen in high resolution. Findings on the CT scan are used to grade splenic injury and guide further management. CT scan can also rule out other concomitant injuries in cases of abdominal trauma, especially injuries involving retroperitoneal structures.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crash

The spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.

Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).

Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a procedure that can be used in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to determine the presence of blood within the peritoneum. DPL should only be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients who have an inconclusive FAST scan. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and a FAST scan was negative for free intraperitoneal fluid. In addition, although highly sensitive, DPL has largely fallen out of favor because it is an invasive procedure; it may, however, be necessary in some cases (e.g., in resource-poor settings).

D) INCORRECT:

Shoulder radiographs are the first-line imaging modality in the diagnostic workup of traumatic shoulder injury (i.e., clavicle, proximal humerus, or scapula fractures; acromioclavicular or glenohumeral dislocations). However, the combination of left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, and a normal shoulder joint examination indicates that this patient's acute shoulder pain is most likely the result of referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) rather than a traumatic shoulder injury.

E) INCORRECT:

An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure that encompasses examination and treatment of the intraabdominal cavity for sources of bleeding in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It is typically performed in hemodynamically unstable patients following the confirmation of free intraperitoneal fluid. This patient is hemodynamically stable and initial diagnostic imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding. Therefore, an exploratory laparotomy is not appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, the onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, as well as a normal shoulder joint examination, indicate that the shoulder pain in this patient most likely results from referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign), and is not the result of a traumatic shoulder injury. If shoulder injury were suspected, a shoulder MRI could be useful to image soft tissue of the shoulder such as the rotator cuff and acromioclavicular ligaments. However, MRI is not the first-line of imaging in a patient with a suspected traumatic shoulder injury.
questions.hint: Left upper quadrant abdominal pain, voluntary guarding, and referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) in a patient who has fallen from a significant height indicates splenic injury.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Remove the knife carefully and apply pressure to the wound
Type and cross for transfusion of packed red blood cells
Arrange for transport to the nearest trauma center

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral tube thoracostomy is indicated in a patient with pneumothorax, pleural effusion, or intrathoracic hemorrhage. These conditions are associated with absent or decreased breath sounds, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. Additionally, the stab wound is below the costal margin and therefore less likely to injure the lungs.

B) INCORRECT:

The knife might be acting as a tamponade on the wound, thereby concealing vascular damage and preventing further hemorrhage. Although emergency surgery is indicated, impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in an operating room where bleeding can be controlled.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient shows signs of active bleeding and will likely need blood transfusions, a type and cross is a blood test that takes time and would not address his primary problem of intraabdominal bleeding from a stab wound.

D) INCORRECT:

Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is the preferred method of endotracheal intubation in emergency settings because it obviates the need for bag valve mask ventilation and decreases the risk of vomiting and aspiration in patients who have not fasted. Although RSI may be indicated in this patient prior to undergoing surgery, immediate RSI is not indicated as he is conscious, has a patent airway, and is not at impending risk of respiratory failure or aspiration.

E) CORRECT:

In this patient with penetrating abdominal trauma, hypotension and tachycardia suggest intraabdominal hemorrhage, which needs to be controlled immediately. Although other lifesaving measures (i.e., fluid resuscitation) should also be conducted as soon as possible and might be done in parallel if more personnel were present, this physician is working alone. To prevent the patient from potentially bleeding to death, immediate transfer to an operating room is indicated. Establishing IV access and setting up fluids may be conducted after arranging transport or on the way to a trauma center. Once the patient is transferred, an exploratory laparotomy should be performed.
questions.hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents to a small community health center after a penetrating abdominal trauma that requires immediate surgery.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department 30 minutes after diving head-first into a shallow pool of water from a cliff. He was placed on a spinal board and a rigid cervical collar was applied by the emergency medical technicians. On arrival, he is unconscious and withdraws all extremities to pain. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 8/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the forehead. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a step-off palpated over the cervical spine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the brain and spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the spine is an appropriate diagnostic test for the management of suspected cervical injuries, but it should only be done after the patient has been stabilized. Although the patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture, the patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

B) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the cervical spine can be considered in the workup of a trauma patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. However, imaging should only be performed after the airway has been secured if there is evidence of respiratory compromise (such as this patient's altered mental status and respiratory rate of 8/min). Moreover, a CT scan would usually be preferable in adult trauma patients with suspected cervical spine injury given its higher sensitivity.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a mechanism of injury and physical examination findings that are consistent with a cervical spine fracture. Given the forehead laceration and the patient's altered mental status, he is also at high risk of intracranial hemorrhage, and a CT scan of both the brain and spine would be helpful in forming a diagnosis. However, the patient's airway is compromised and he shows signs of respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the CT scanner.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's mechanism of injury and physical examination are both consistent with a cervical fracture that is complicated by altered mental status with respiratory insufficiency (respiratory rate of 8/min). Rapid sequence intubation is vital to secure the patient's airway and allow for proper management of his cervical injury. Cervical fractures may lead to immediate or delayed cervical spinal cord compression and/or phrenic nerve paralysis and subsequent respiratory failure. Although an oxygen saturation of 96% may seem reassuring, hypercapnic respiratory failure may manifest with normal pulse oximetry. Delaying intubation in favor of imaging could lead to respiratory arrest, seizure, and death.

See “Primary trauma survey”.

E) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal mask airway devices are not the recommended method of airway management in an unconscious patient with impaired respiratory status, especially in a trauma setting, where a laryngeal mask might exacerbate occult esophageal injury. They may be used in the case of failed intubation due to a difficult airway, but intubation has not yet been attempted.

F) INCORRECT:

Rectal tone assessment is performed during the Disability or Exposure portions of the primary trauma survey. As such, it should not be performed until after the Airway, Breathing, and Circulation portions of the primary survey have been completed, especially in a patient who is unconscious and has a respiratory rate of 8/min.

G) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the spine may be used for the diagnosis of traumatic spinal cord injury as well as presurgical planning. However, this patient's respiratory status is compromised (he is unconscious and his respiratory rate is 8/min). Delaying airway management in favor of imaging could be devastating if the patient were to decompensate inside the MRI scanner. Moreover, a CT scan would be preferable in most trauma patients, given its much shorter duration.
questions.hint: This patient has likely sustained a cervical spine injury that is compromising his respiratory function.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after a bicycle accident. He was cycling downhill at approximately 30 miles per hour when he lost control at a curve in the road. He was wearing a helmet and did not lose consciousness. There is no personal history of serious illness and he takes no medications. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented. He is placed on a backboard with a cervical collar around his neck. Pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over the forehead and right cheek. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 2-cm laceration below the right ear. Both ear canals show no abnormalities. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mild midline cervical spine tenderness as well as tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) shows no free intraperitoneal fluid. Bedside chest x-ray shows a fracture of the 3rd rib on the right side and no other abnormalities. ECG is normal. Two peripheral venous catheters are placed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the cervical spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal CT scan is an important diagnostic tool for patients with blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents with abdominal tenderness but does not require CT scan at this time because he has no signs of abdominal injury, is hemodynamically stable, and has a negative FAST scan.

B) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the neck may be used to initially assess for cervical spine injury, which must be ruled out in this patient, but another test has a higher sensitivity and is preferred whenever available.

C) INCORRECT:

Brain imaging may be indicated for patients with blunt head injury to assess for traumatic intracranial lesions (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage). This patient did not lose consciousness, has a normal mental status, no focal neurological deficits, and no risk factors for intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., bleeding disorder, anticoagulation), making a traumatic intracranial lesion unlikely. Additionally, if this patient did require brain imaging, a CT scan of the head without contrast would be the initial test of choice because it is more readily available and results can be rapidly obtained.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with blunt neck trauma, cervical spine imaging is required to rule out injury if at least one of the NEXUS cervical spine criteria is met: focal neurological deficit, posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness, altered consciousness, intoxication, and/or distracting injury. A CT scan of the cervical spine is the preferred imaging modality to rule out cervical spine injury in adult trauma patients.

If none of the NEXUS criteria are present, the risk of cervical spine injury is low, meaning that imaging is not indicated and the cervical collar can be removed.

E) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the wrist can be used to rule out an underlying fracture. Although this patient has signs of potential wrist fracture (wrist pain, tenderness, limited range of motion), more severe injuries must be ruled out first. The patient's wrist will eventually require imaging and treatment. In trauma resuscitation, management of nonlethal injuries such as a wrist fracture is often deferred until all life threats are stabilized. Until that time, fractured limbs are often splinted for patient comfort.
questions.hint: This patient's midline cervical tenderness raises concern for a possible cervical spine injury.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. She was found thrown across the dashboard of the car. On arrival, she appears lethargic. She is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 133/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the right upper extremity. There are multiple bruises over the chest and abdomen. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate in the management of this patient, who presents after blunt abdominal trauma with altered mental status, multiple bruises, and unstable vital signs. This patient needs urgent workup and treatment for the cause of her hemodynamic instability.

B) INCORRECT:

Exploratory laparotomy is the first step in managing blunt abdominal trauma if signs of peritoneal irritation are present. However, this patient has no signs of peritoneal irritation, and other diagnostic approaches must first be considered to investigate why this patient is hemodynamically unstable. In the case that no other diagnostic resources are readily available, exploratory laparotomy should be performed if there is high clinical suspicion of intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen would not be the next best step for managing this unstable patient. Although a CT scan can also show the presence of a hemoperitoneum, it takes time and unnecessarily exposes the patient to radiation when other more rapid diagnostic studies are available.

D) CORRECT:

Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is an essential component of management for blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision and is hemodynamically unstable, which is concerning for intraperitoneal bleeding. The FAST exam screens for free fluid, especially blood, in the right upper quadrant, left upper quadrant, pericardial space, and pelvis.

E) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) would not be the most appropriate next step because other less invasive and more readily available diagnostic studies should be available to assess for intraabdominal bleeding. A DPL can be considered when other diagnostic studies are unavailable or equivocal.
questions.hint: Intraabdominal bleeding should be ruled out in an unstable trauma patient initially with a noninvasive, easily accessible imaging modality.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department because of an episode of acute psychosis with suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. Despite appropriate safety precautions, he manages to leave the examination room unattended. Shortly afterward, he is found lying outside the emergency department. A visitor reports that she saw the patient climbing up the facade of the hospital building. He does not respond to questions but points to his head when asked about pain. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows a 1-cm head laceration and an open fracture of the right tibia. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Breath sounds are decreased over the right lung field, and the upper right hemithorax is hyperresonant to percussion. There is no jugular venous distension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Place two large bore IV catheters and start two bags of 0.9% saline
Perform open reduction of the tibia fracture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracostomy is indicated for tension pneumothorax causing respiratory compromise. Although this patient likely has pneumothorax (hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on examination), he currently does not have signs of severe acute respiratory distress resulting from tension pneumothorax (e.g., jugular venous distention, tracheal deviation, cyanosis). Airway protection should take place before managing a potential tension pneumothorax that is not causing respiratory compromise. Close monitoring for deterioration, for which needle thoracostomy may become necessary, is also indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation is indicated for patients with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8 or less because these patients often cannot maintain their airway. This patient has a GCS of 11: He opens his eyes spontaneously (eye opening = 4), obeys commands by localizing pain (motor response = 6), and does not respond verbally to questions (verbal response = 1). Although this patient currently does not need intubation for airway protection, he is still at risk for an injury that further compromises his airway; therefore, part “A” of the ABCDE approach needs to be addressed first.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with blunt trauma to the head and neck, a cervical spine injury should be assumed until proven otherwise. The fact that this patient does not respond verbally to questions despite being conscious raises concern that his airway is compromised. This patient needs a cervical collar to immobilize the cervical spine, ensuring protection of his airway from further damage. This step addresses part “A” (airway assessment and protection) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients.

To diagnose or exclude cervical spine injury, x-ray and CT scan, as well as a physical examination in the form of cervical spine palpation for tenderness, are performed.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient will need intravenous fluids to increase his blood pressure of 105/69 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid administration addresses the “C” (circulation and hemorrhage control) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients. Before the administration of fluids, however, this patient needs airway protection; airway (“A”) compromise is more immediately life-threatening than hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

A neurological examination is appropriate once the airway, respiratory (breathing), and circulatory status of this patient have been addressed (parts “A” through “C” of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients). The neurological examination is part “D” of the ABCDE approach to neurological disability assessment.

F) INCORRECT:

An x-ray in this patient will eventually be necessary to help identify possible rib fractures and pulmonary conditions such as pneumothorax and/or hemothorax. Because this patient likely suffered severe blunt trauma to the head and neck, he may have sustained an airway-compromising injury. Such an injury must be adequately addressed before an x-ray is obtained.

G) INCORRECT:

Open reduction of the tibia fracture is not the most appropriate next step in treating this patient who may have an injury that compromises his airway. Before the tibia fracture can be addressed, the ABCDE approach to trauma management needs to be completed in alphabetical order, with an emphasis on “A” or airway management and protection in the patient.
questions.hint: Remember the ABCDE approach to trauma management.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Video laryngoscopy allows for visualization of the oropharynx and is commonly used to facilitate orotracheal intubation in patients with a difficult airway. Although video laryngoscopy could have been used earlier in the management of this patient, several intubation attempts have been unsuccessful. Furthermore, his oxygen saturation is acutely dropping despite attempts at maintaining ventilation and oxygenation through bag-valve and laryngeal masks. If establishing an alternative airway via video laryngoscopy is unsuccessful, hypoxic brain injury may occur. Another step is more appropriate in an emergency setting.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has just suffered major trauma, and his preferred code status is unknown. It would be highly inappropriate to change his code status to comfort measures only in the absence of an advance directive, a health care proxy, and before all possible treatment modalities have been exhausted.

C) INCORRECT:

Although an emergency tracheostomy may be performed in a CICV scenario, this approach is usually not the first-line option because it is more complex and time-consuming, and causes more bleeding than other emergency surgical airway procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

A nasotracheal approach can be attempted to achieve intubation in patients with a difficult airway and limited oral access (e.g., due to oropharyngeal obstruction). However, this technique is usually performed electively in the operating room under direct visualization of the pharynx with laryngoscopy. Nasopharyngeal intubation is time-consuming and is therefore inappropriate in a CICV scenario with declining oxygen saturation, which requires an emergency airway.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has just experienced major trauma and presents with signs of respiratory distress (respiratory rate of 10/min, oxygen saturation of 84%), neurological compromise (lethargy, sluggish pupils), and a compromised airway (decreased breath sounds over left hemithorax, rapid decrease in oxygen saturation). After unsuccessful attempts at securing the airway and ventilation via orotracheal intubation, laryngeal mask placement, and bag-mask ventilation, immediate action is required to prevent hypoxia. A surgical airway with cricothyrotomy should be established in patients who cannot be intubated and oxygenated. Cricothyrotomy is the preferred method in an emergency when rapid airway control is needed, especially in cases where intubation is unsuccessful, and other supraglottic airway devices are ineffective.
Image Description:

Diagram showing an emergency cricothyroidotomy, which is typically performed if attempts to intubate have been unsuccessful. An incision is made through the cricothyroid membrane, and a cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted through the incision site. Cricothyroidotomy allows ventilation of the patient until a more definitive airway is placed.
questions.hint: This patient is in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate (CICV) scenario with increasing hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after falling off a 3-m (10-foot) ladder. He has severe pain and swelling of his right ankle and is unable to walk. He did not lose consciousness after the fall. He has no nausea. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows multiple abrasions over both lower extremities. There is swelling and tenderness of the right ankle; range of motion is limited by pain. Dorsalis pedis and tibialis posterior pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the ankle shows an extra-articular calcaneal fracture. Intravenous analgesia is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although an MRI might provide more information about the fracture (which may be useful for deciding on a treatment approach, especially in the case of an intra-articular fracture) and any associated soft tissue damage, there is a different intervention that should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient sustained a high-energy trauma injury, which warrants further study and treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

A long leg cast may be indicated for some fractures, particularly of the distal femur, patella, tibia, and/or fibula, none of which are the case in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation are indicated in cases of displaced, open, or pathologic fractures, or fractures involving neurovascular compromise, none of which are the case in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

A CT scan of the spine to rule out spinal injury is indicated for a patient with any of the following: high-energy trauma, distracting injury, intoxication, focal neurological deficit, altered mental status, or spinal tenderness. A fall from a height ≥ 3 m (10 ft) is an example of high-energy trauma and this patient's calcaneal fracture is a distracting injury. Following a fall from a height, the patients can develop axial loading injuries, such as vertebral compression fractures or burst fractures.
questions.hint: 10–15% of calcaneal fractures are associated with another pathology due to the axial transmission of force.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department after being injured by a dresser falling on him. When the child tried to pull himself up on the dresser, it tipped and fell on his chest and abdomen. He had been awake and agitated at the scene and moved all extremities except for his right arm. On arrival, he is unconscious with rapid, shallow respirations. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 164/min and thready, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 68/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bony deformity of the right upper extremity and scattered ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. The abdomen is distended with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Attempts to obtain venous access were not successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Central venous line insertion into the right subclavian vein
Peripherally inserted central catheter insertion into the left basilic vein
Peripheral intravenous line insertion into the left dorsal hand veins
Venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein
Peripheral venous line insertion into the left external jugular vein
Intraosseous line insertion into the right humerus
Intraosseous line insertion into the left proximal tibia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Central venous lines (CVLs) can be placed for various reasons, including inadequate peripheral venous access, hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medication. However, this patient presents with signs of severe hypovolemia requiring immediate fluid resuscitation. Subclavian vein cannulation performed during emergencies is accompanied by a variety of complications such as hemothorax or pneumothorax. In addition, CVL insertion requires ultrasound guidance, which would consume valuable time in an emergency such as this. Lastly, since flow rates in CVLs are relatively low given the length of the catheter, a CVL is not the preferred access for emergency fluid resuscitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Indications for placement of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) include inadequate peripheral venous access, the need for hemodynamic monitoring, and administration of medications such as vasopressors or chemotherapy, which can cause phlebitis when administered through a peripheral IV catheter. Although high-volume fluid therapy can be administered using central catheters, it is not the preferred vascular access for emergencies because central line placement is usually performed under ultrasound guidance and its proper placement is checked by x-ray, which consumes valuable time.

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral IV line insertion is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. However, obtaining peripheral venous access has already been attempted without success and the patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation. Particularly in pediatric trauma patients such as this one, peripheral IV access should be achieved within 60–90 seconds of arrival. If vascular access cannot be obtained in this time, alternative access routes should be considered because another attempt at placing a peripheral IV line would only delay treatment and risk organ damage or even death.

D) INCORRECT:

Saphenous venous cutdown is a technique used to obtain emergency venous access. However, venous cutdown is time-consuming and has lower placement success rates and higher infectious complication rates compared to other means of vascular access. Although peripheral venous access could not be obtained immediately in this patient, venous cutdown of the great left saphenous vein should only be attempted if other forms of vascular access have also been unsuccessful.

E) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a peripheral IV line is the preferred venous access for fluid resuscitation in trauma patients. Although insertion into the left external jugular vein can be performed by experienced physicians, it should not be used as a primary site in children with airway compromise or respiratory failure because it requires extension as well as rotation of the neck, thereby putting the patient at unnecessary risk of exacerbating symptoms. Another attempt of placing a peripheral IV line would only delay appropriate treatment and increase the patient's risk of complications (e.g., organ damage), meaning that alternative access routes should be considered.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraosseous (IO) cannulation permits rapid intravascular access for both pediatric and adult patients and is obtained in emergencies because it has a very high success rate. This patient presents with a deformity of the right upper extremity suggestive of a fracture. IO infusion has few absolute contraindications, which include bone fractures, bones previously punctured by IO cannulation, and extremities with vascular interruption because fluids might extravasate into tissue and put the patient at risk for compartment syndrome. In addition, while the humerus is commonly used for IO line insertion in adults, other locations are more frequently used in children.

G) CORRECT:

Severe hypovolemia in children requires immediate and rapid IV fluid replacement (20 mL/kg) and continuous monitoring until adequate perfusion is reestablished. Since venous access could not be obtained in this patient, an intraosseous (IO) access should be placed. The proximal tibia is the preferred site for IO lines, especially in pediatric patients, as it has the highest success rate.
questions.hint: This pediatric patient who suffered blunt abdominal trauma presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and ecchymoses over the chest and abdomen, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. He requires immediate fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after being involved in a shooting. He sustained a gunshot wound in an altercation outside of a bar. On arrival, he is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 79/42 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over the arms and thorax. There is a 1-cm (0.4-in) entry wound with minimal bleeding on the right side of the chest in the 6th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. A focused assessment with sonography shows no obvious free fluid in the pericardium; assessment of the abdomen is equivocal. An x-ray of the chest shows mild opacification of the right lower lobe. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Chest tube insertion in the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line
Needle thoracostomy in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line
CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a chest tube into the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line is indicated for hemothorax, which can develop as a result of a gunshot wound. Although a hemothorax can manifest with lower lobe opacification on chest x-ray, blunting of the costophrenic angle is also expected. Moreover, dyspnea and diminished breath sounds are likely to be present.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopnea

The margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.

Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

B) INCORRECT:

Insertion of a needle into the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line is a technique used for emergency decompression of tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax may develop as a result of a gunshot wound and manifests with chest pain, dyspnea, unilateral decreased breath sounds, contralateral deviation of the trachea, and hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia, etc). However, this patient has a normal pulmonary examination and no signs of pneumothorax on chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan is used to assess patients with penetrating abdominal wounds if they are stable on examination. It helps detect intraabdominal bleeding and assess the extent of the injury. A CT scan is not indicated in this hemodynamically unstable patient because there is a risk that his state may worsen in the time it takes to obtain the scan. Patients without signs of peritonitis, evisceration, or hemodynamic instability may undergo CT prior to surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Local wound exploration can be used to evaluate the depth and tract of stab wounds and to determine if peritoneal violation has occurred. However, it would not be appropriate in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with penetrating abdominal injury who are hemodynamically unstable require an exploratory laparotomy. Gunshot wounds commonly injure the small bowel, colon, and liver, and a FAST exam cannot rule out all sources of abdominal bleeding. During expiration, the dome of the diaphragm may reach as high as the fourth intercostal space on the right and the fifth intercostal space on the left. For this reason, any penetrating injury below this level is treated as if it involves both the thoracic and abdominal cavities. Although this patient may also have a diaphragmatic and/or pulmonary injury, as indicated by the right lower lobe opacity seen on chest x-ray, this is unlikely to be responsible for his hypotension and tachycardia. Given the site of injury and equivocal FAST exam, an exploratory laparotomy is indicated to assess for potential intraabdominal injuries that may be the cause of his hemodynamic instability.

Other indications for emergency laparotomy include evisceration, signs of peritonitis (abdominal pain with guarding/rebound tenderness), and free air under the diaphragm.

F) INCORRECT:

In the setting of penetrating chest trauma, video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is mainly used to diagnose and treat suspected diaphragmatic injuries in hemodynamically stable patients. Injury to the diaphragm may result in a variety of features (based on whether it is penetrating or blunt), but patients usually present with ventilatory issues such as dyspnea and decreased breath sounds. In this patient, the location of injury and opacities seen in the right lower lobe on chest x-ray suggest a diaphragmatic and/or pulmonary injury. However, in a patient who is hemodynamically unstable and shows no clinical signs of a thoracic injury (normal pulmonary examination, no signs of severe injury on chest x-ray), another procedure is indicated that is more likely to allow for identification and treatment of the source of shock.

G) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is indicated in the setting of abdominal trauma when no definitive source of bleeding is identified on imaging (e.g., FAST, CT scan) and an intraabdominal injury is suspected. This procedure is especially useful for inspecting the diaphragm and determining the feasibility of nonoperative management of isolated solid organ injury. However, this procedure is reserved for hemodynamically stable patients and is therefore not indicated in this patient.
questions.hint: Any penetrating trauma located anteriorly below the nipple line (fourth intercostal space) is considered a potential trauma of both the thorax and the abdomen.

questions.text: A 27-year-old soldier stationed in Libya sustains a shrapnel injury during an attack, causing a traumatic above-elbow amputation. The resulting arterial bleed is managed with a tourniquet prior to transport to the military treatment facility. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His armor and clothing are removed. His pulse is 145/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 95/52 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows symmetric chest rise. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. There are multiple shrapnel wounds over the upper and lower extremities. A tourniquet is in place around the right upper extremity; the right proximal forearm has been amputated. One large-bore intravenous catheter is placed in the left antecubital fossa. Despite multiple attempts, medical staff is unable to establish additional intravenous access. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Replace the tourniquet with a pressure dressing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irrigation of the shrapnel wounds with fluid is part of routine wound management and essential for reducing the risk of infection. However, this patient is in acute hemorrhagic shock that requires immediate treatment. Therefore, a different procedure is the next best step in management.

B) INCORRECT:

Establishment of an additional line for fluid resuscitation is essential in this patient with acute hemorrhagic shock. However, placing a central venous line is too time-consuming and, therefore, not appropriate at this time. Central venous access may be useful in the further management of this patient, especially if transfusion of large volumes of fluids and/or blood products or prolonged infusions of vasopressors are expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Pressure dressings are the preferred method of hemorrhage control as they rarely cause complications such as limb ischemia. Therefore, tourniquets placed as a first measure to control bleeding should be replaced by pressure dressings as soon as the patient is stable and the clinical situation allows it. However, this patient is in acute hemorrhagic shock, which takes priority and requires further management. Attempting to release the tourniquet and thereby risking recurrent hemorrhage can potentially exacerbate this patient's hemodynamic instability. It is, therefore, not indicated at this time.

D) CORRECT:

Management of trauma patients follows the ABCDE approach. This patient's airway (A) and breathing (B) have been assessed and are stable (conscious patient with symmetric chest rise, lungs clear to auscultation). Although hemorrhage control has been achieved with the application of a tourniquet, this patient's vital signs (hypotension, tachycardia) indicate circulatory (C) failure. Immediate administration of intravenous fluids in order to restore and maintain adequate tissue perfusion is vital. The standard trauma protocol of establishing intravenous access via two large-bore lines is not possible; one intravenous line is not sufficient for large-volume fluid resuscitation in this patient with life-threatening hemorrhage. Therefore, establishing intraosseous access is the most appropriate next step in management. Then, disability (D) is assessed via evaluation of the patient's neurological status, and exposure (E) of the patient is performed to allow a thorough evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation of a trauma patient is indicated in the case of severe respiratory distress, unconsciousness or severely impaired mental state (GCS < 8), and/or major injuries to the face and neck. None of these indications are present in this patient, whose tachypnea is most likely secondary to hypovolemic shock. Intubation is, therefore, not necessary.
questions.hint: This patient's vital signs indicate hemorrhagic shock. Management should focus on rapid fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 1 hour after being tackled by a bull on his ranch. Immediately after being knocked over, he had pain in his right lower thoracic region. Twenty minutes later, he became dizzy. His wife says he has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he barely responds to painful stimuli. His temperature is 36ºC (96.8ºF), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 76/62 mm Hg. No source of bleeding is seen besides small lacerations on his extremities. There is a significant ecchymosis in the right lower thoracic region and the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Chest auscultation shows no abnormalities. Peripheral venous access is established, blood samples for crossmatching and blood gas analysis are drawn, and rapid infusion of Ringer lactate (RL) solution is initiated. The patient is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. A FAST scan of the abdomen discloses blood in the hepatorenal recess. After the administration of 1000 mL of RL solution, the patient's blood pressure is 80/64 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate fluid resuscitation with hydroxyethyl starch solution
Transfuse O group, Rh negative packed red blood cells
Perform CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage used to be commonly performed in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to identify intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Since the advent of FAST scan, however, this invasive procedure is no longer preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluid resuscitation with hydroxyethyl starch solution is associated with an increased risk of kidney dysfunction and mortality and should generally be avoided in critically ill patients.

C) CORRECT:

Patients in shock with a history of, or ongoing, severe hemorrhage should receive an initial bolus of intravenous saline followed by transfusion of type O Rh negative packed red blood cells (pRBCs). If available, fully crossmatched pRBCs are preferable for this purpose. Early resuscitation with blood reestablishes hemoglobin levels and, therefore, the oxygen-carrying capacity of the intravascular volume. The reestablished capacity prevents organ ischemia and associated metabolic acidosis, both of which can complicate shock. If hemorrhage is extensive and the patient continues to be hemodynamically unstable, plasma and platelets should be transfused in addition to pRBCs at a 1:1:1 ratio. Transfusion of these blood products counters the risk of developing coagulopathy, which is another complication of shock associated with acidosis, hypothermia, trauma itself, fibrinolysis, and dilution due to fluid transfusion. In addition to transfusion of pRBCs, management of this patient should include immediate transfer to the operating room for laparotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen is indicated after blunt trauma in hemodynamically stable patients if an initial FAST scan is inconclusive. This patient, however, is in hemorrhagic shock and hemodynamically unstable. Furthermore, the results of the FAST scan in conjunction with this patient's history of trauma and physical examination findings are conclusive for intraperitoneal bleeding due to liver laceration.

E) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine infusion to maintain organ perfusion is indicated in patients with hypotension due to septic or cardiogenic shock. This patient, however, has hypovolemic shock. Vasopressors such as norepinephrine should be avoided in this condition because these drugs do not treat the cause of hypovolemia and can lead to organ hypoperfusion and tissue damage (e.g., kidney injury).

F) INCORRECT:

Recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa) is approved for the treatment of hemorrhage in patients with hemophilia A and B, acquired hemophilia, factor VII deficiency, or Glanzmann thrombasthenia. rFVIIa is also used off-label in patients with coagulopathy due to trauma. Although this patient has a history of trauma, there are no signs of coagulopathy (e.g., mucosal bleeding, hematoma).
questions.hint: This patient has a history of blunt trauma and presents with tachycardia, hypotension with decreased pulse pressure, tachypnea, and intraperitoneal blood, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. The bleeding most likely comes from liver laceration caused by a rib fracture (as suggested by ecchymosis on the right lower chest). The next step in management should increase blood pressure and ensure oxygen delivery to the tissue.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple stab wounds and blunt trauma to his chest during a gang fight. On arrival, he has severe chest pain that worsens on inspiration and coughs intermittently. He is alert and in moderate respiratory distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 85/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. There are multiple entrance wounds and ecchymoses on his chest and upper back. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade is a severe complication of chest trauma and can manifest with sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, a chest x-ray would show an enlarged heart silhouette (a water bottle sign in the case of large effusions) with clear lungs rather than mediastinal shift, depressed right hemidiaphragm, and widened right intercostal spaces. In addition to hypotension, cardiac tamponade usually causes muffled heart sounds and distended neck veins (Beck triad).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lupus pericarditis

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and demonstrates a globular, or water bottle, configuration due to pericardial effusion (green hatched overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary contusion can develop following blunt chest trauma and manifest with respiratory distress and chest pain. However, chest x-ray typically shows diffuse patchy alveolar infiltrates and white-out or diffuse opacities, not a mediastinal shift, depressed right hemidiaphragm, and widened right intercostal spaces.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumomediastinum can occur following penetrating chest trauma and manifests with respiratory distress, cough, and chest pain. However, a chest x-ray typically shows a radiolucent outline around the mediastinal structures. Moreover, pneumomediastinum also manifests with subcutaneous emphysema and the Hamman sign.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with left chest trauma

Acute fractures of the posterior left 3rd through 7th ribs are accompanied by tension pneumothorax, with depression of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by white arrow) and a rightward shift of the mediastinum (indicated by red arrow). The left lung is partially collapsed (green overlay). Pneumomediastinum, or mediastinal emphysema, is visible as vertically oriented linear lucencies in the mediastinum (examples indicated by yellow overlay). Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and left chest wall is the result of the dissection of mediastinal air into the soft tissues (examples indicated by blue overlay). Air outlining fibers of the pectoralis muscle produces the ginkgo-leaf sign (indicated by red overlay).

Healed fractures of the right 6th, 7th, and 9th ribs are also visible, and an ECG electrode projects over the anterior aspect of the right 2nd rib.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and chest x-ray findings (absence of right bronchovascular markings and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side) after multiple penetrating injuries to the chest indicate a tension pneumothorax. This condition is caused by air trapping in the pleural space, which, if severe enough, can compress the adjacent structures (e.g., contralateral lung, mediastinum) and impair venous return to the heart. This can cause life-threatening cardiopulmonary collapse, which manifests with severe hypotension and tachycardia. Emergency needle thoracostomy, followed by chest tube placement, is the first-line treatment for patients with suspected tension pneumothorax.

Emergency chest tube thoracostomy is indicated in unstable patients, who present with bilateral tension pneumothorax or require mechanical ventilation.
Image Description:

A tension pneumothorax develops secondary to one-way valve mechanism, which is caused by an injury to the lung parenchyma or chest wall and allows air to enter the pleural space during inspiration (valve open) but not escape during expiration (valve closed). Progressive accumulation of air within the pleural space causes an ipsilateral increase in intrapleural pressure, leading to ipsilateral lung collapse and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side. The mediastinal shift compresses the vena cavae, trachea, and the contralateral lung, leading to hemodynamic instability and hypoxia.

E) INCORRECT:

An acquired diaphragmatic hernia can be caused by blunt or penetrating thoracoabdominal trauma and usually manifests with the sudden onset of respiratory distress and chest pain. However, a chest x-ray typically shows hemidiaphragm elevation rather than depression, and a chest translucency or opacity with an air-fluid level (representing the stomach or bowel) would also be expected in a patient with an acquired diaphragmatic hernia.

F) INCORRECT:

A flail chest can result from blunt trauma and would explain this patient's acute onset of dyspnea, tachypnea, and the presence of chest ecchymoses. However, this condition is typically characterized by paradoxical chest movement, which this patient does not have. Moreover, the chest x-ray does not show any rib fractures, which makes the diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs
questions.hint: Chest x-ray shows a depressed hemidiaphragm and widened intercostal spaces on the right side and a left mediastinal shift.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after she was found face down in a pool by her older brother. The siblings were playing outside in the garden of their grandparents. The brother reports that he went inside to get something to drink and discovered his sister floating in the pool when he returned. The grandfather took her out of the pool and called an ambulance. On arrival, paramedics found that the girl was somnolent but spontaneously breathing. On route to the hospital, they initiated bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 34.2°C (93.5°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen administered via a nonrebreather mask shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. There is no evidence of trauma to the head or neck; the lips appear bluish. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. The airway is clear. Pulmonary auscultation shows diffuse crackles and wheezing. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Cover in warm blankets and observe for at least 8 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation for at least 8 hours is indicated for all patients who experience nonfatal drowning, including asymptomatic patients, because of the risk of late respiratory complications due to alveolar damage and surfactant washout. While this patient's treatment should include external warming measures, she is somnolent and has evidence of respiratory distress; a different step in management should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypoxic brain injury can occur after submersion injury. Patients with an impaired level of consciousness or other signs of brain injury should be evaluated with neuroimaging, such as CT scan or MRI. Although adjuncts (e.g., imaging) are included in the primary survey, the initial steps for treating patients with hypoxic brain injuries focus on stabilizing the patient. Moreover, MRIs are time-consuming and can delay lifesaving treatment. An MRI may be considered for this patient once she has been stabilized.

C) CORRECT:

Ensuring oxygenation is the most important goal in the management of submersion injury because aspirated fluid can damage the alveolar membranes and wash out surfactant, leading to hypoxia. In this patient who is tachypneic, somnolent, and unable to maintain an SpO2 of 90% despite the use of a nonrebreather mask, endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are indicated to improve oxygenation and protect the airway. After intubation, an orogastric tube should be placed to relieve gastric distention caused by water that may have entered passively during submersion. Continuous ECG monitoring is necessary to assess for arrhythmias. Finally, wet clothes must be removed and the patient rewarmed.

For asymptomatic patients, continuous observation is required as submersion injuries can manifest with a delayed onset of symptoms. Submersion injuries in children can be prevented by safe practices and interventions (e.g., fencing off pools, use of life jackets, swimming lessons, adult supervision, lifeguards).

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloids may be appropriate to treat hypothermia in children, along with other rewarming measures such as the removal of wet clothing and covering the patient with hot air blankets. Hypothermia commonly occurs after submersion injuries and should be addressed in this patient. However, addressing hypothermia is part of the final stage of the ABCDE approach (E: exposure).

E) INCORRECT:

During submersion injuries, surfactant can be washed out, which can lead to respiratory distress and hypoxia. However, there is no evidence to support the administration of exogenous surfactant in the treatment of patients with hypoxia following submersion injuries.

F) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine injury should always be suspected in patients who have experienced blunt trauma, e.g., due to a fall or motor vehicle collision accident. However, submersion injuries are rarely associated with cervical spine injuries if there is no evidence (e.g., abrasion or laceration) or history (e.g., diving into shallow water) to suggest head or neck trauma. Immobilization of the cervical spine is not routinely recommended in patients with submersion injury.
questions.hint: The ABCDE approach should be followed in all cases of trauma, which includes drowning.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest during an attempted robbery. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a knife in situ that enters the thoracic wall just above the 7th rib in the left midaxillary line. The right lung is clear to auscultation; auscultation of the left lung and cardiac examination remain inconclusive as the patient does not tolerate being examined near the entrance wound. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal pain without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Five minutes later, the patient becomes unresponsive. Repeat vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 88/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST)
Removal of the knife with direct pressure on the wound
CT scan of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency tube thoracostomy is the treatment of choice when hemodynamic instability is caused by tension pneumothorax or hemothorax. Tube thoracostomy should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for the underlying condition (e.g., absent breath sounds on auscultation and hyperresonance to percussion in a patient with pneumothorax). This patient's auscultation findings remain inconclusive, so tube thoracostomy is not indicated at this point.

B) CORRECT:

Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) is typically used during the primary ABCDE survey and subsequent reassessments of patients with penetrating chest trauma to establish a diagnosis and guide management. eFAST is especially useful for hemodynamically unstable patients because it is fast, comprehensive (includes views of the heart and both hemithoraces to detect cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and/or pneumothorax), and can be discontinued at any point. In cases of hemodynamic instability where there is a strong clinical suspicion of cardiac tamponade (e.g., muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins) or tension pneumothorax (e.g., absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion on the ipsilateral side), emergency pericardiocentesis or tube thoracostomy, respectively, should not be delayed by imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from penetrating chest trauma and manifest with hemodynamic instability. Pericardiocentesis should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for this condition (e.g., muffled heart sounds on auscultation, distended jugular veins). This patient's cardiac auscultation remains inconclusive, so pericardiocentesis is not indicated at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Penetrating objects often tamponade the wound, so removal can cause further hemorrhage. Removal should therefore only be performed in settings where definitive care is possible (i.e., by a surgeon in an operating room), preferably not in the emergency department.

E) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest and abdomen can be used to assess patients with penetrating chest trauma. It is important to consider concomitant intraabdominal injuries in cases of penetrating trauma below the nipples, which this patient has. However, CT scans should not be performed on hemodynamically unstable patients who are at risk of further deterioration while undergoing the scan.
questions.hint: This patient has sustained penetrating chest trauma, which can result in a number of potentially life-threatening conditions (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax, hemopericardium, hemoperitoneum, organ laceration). Since the patient has become hemodynamically unstable (hypotension, tachycardia), speed and comprehensiveness in assessing and treating the underlying condition are essential.

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.
